fullText:
PHYSICAL REVIEW C, VOLUME 62, 057301Inelastic excitation of new high-spin yrast isomers in 180Ta
C. Wheldon,1,* P. M. Walker,1 P. Chowdhury,2 I. Shestakova,2 R. D’Alarcao,2 I. Ahmad,3 M. P. Carpenter,3
D. M. Cullen,4,† R. V. F. Janssens,3 T. L. Khoo,3 F. G. Kondev,3 C. J. Lister,3 C. J. Pearson,1 Zs. Podolya`k,1
D. Seweryniak,3 and I. Wiedenhoever3
1Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford GU2 7XH, United Kingdom
2University of Massachusetts, Lowell, Massachusetts 01854
3Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439
4Department of Physics, Oliver Lodge Laboratory, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 7ZE, United Kingdom
~Received 1 June 2000; published 25 September 2000!
For the first time, six-quasiparticle isomers have been observed in the meta-stable nucleus 73
180Ta107 . Two
new high-spin isomers were populated following deep-inelastic reactions with a pulsed 92
238U beam incident on
a thick 72
180Hf target. Out-of-beam g-ray events were collected using the Gammasphere germanium detector
array. In addition to the known four-quasiparticle isomers, yrast Kp5(222) and K>23 six-quasiparticle
isomers have been observed with microsecond half-lives. These are the highest-spin isomers observed using
the technique of deep-inelastic excitation. The assignments are compared to predictions made by BCS and
Lipkin-Nogami multiquasiparticle calculations.
PACS number~s!: 21.10.Tg, 23.20.Lv, 27.70.1qThe structure and excitations of the rare isotope 180Ta are
of considerable current interest, for example Refs. @1–3#,
arising from its unique status as the only isotope to occur
naturally in an isomeric state. The 11 ground-state has a
half-life of only 8 hours, whereas an excited 92 state lying at
75 keV, has a lifetime of .1015 years. The direct decay of
this isomer is highly hindered due to a combination of its low
excitation energy and high spin, relative to the ground state.
Several studies have attempted to explain the production and
survival of this spin-trap isomer in stellar environments,
most recently Ref. @1#.
This odd-odd nucleus with 73 protons and 107 neutrons
lies in a region of the nuclear chart where large prolate de-
formations are energetically favored. This leads to partial
conservation of the angular momentum projection K on the
nuclear symmetry axis @4#. The decay of these intrinsic states
to the competing collective rotational levels is hindered, pro-
viding a sensitive probe of the underlying structure of the
nucleus.
Previous experiments to study the yrast structure of 180Ta
have used light heavy-ion projectiles, namely, 511 B and 37Li
on targets of 176Yb @2,3#. Several new isomers have been
observed using these partial fusion and fusion-evaporation
reactions, including a 31 ms Kp5152 four-quasiparticle
state @5#. However, this technique is limited to ;20 \ of
angular momentum. Recently, experiments using deep-
inelastic reactions @6–8# have enabled states with spins up to
;30 \ to be reached @9# and K isomers have been populated
in neutron-rich nuclei that cannot be accessed using fusion-
evaporation reactions with stable beams and targets @10–12#.
The first isomers at spins .20 \ , using this method of trans-
fer and inelastic excitation are now reported.
*Present address: Department of Physics, Oliver Lodge Labora-
tory, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 7ZE, UK.
†Present address: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Univer-
sity of Manchester, Manchester M13 9PL, UK.0556-2813/2000/62~5!/057301~4!/$15.00 62 0573A 1.6 GeV pulsed 92
238U beam provided by the ATLAS
accelerator facility at Argonne National Laboratory was used
to bombard a thick target (’40 mg cm22) of 72180Hf, backed
by >50 mg cm22 of natPb. The beam energy was chosen to
be 15% above the Coulomb barrier, consistent with Refs.
@11,12#. The target was enriched to 98.2% in 180Hf, the
heaviest stable isotope, to favor the population of neutron-
rich products. The natural pulsing period of the beam is 82.5
ns, and this was swept on two longer time ranges with ON/
OFF conditions of 8.25 ms/16.5 ms and 2 ms/4 ms ~corre-
sponding to 100/200 and 24 250/48 500 beam bursts, respec-
tively!. All of the recoils were stopped at the target position
at the focus of the Gammasphere array, comprised of 98
g-ray Compton-suppressed germanium detectors and 3
Compton-suppressed planar x-ray germanium detectors. The
trigger condition required at least one germanium detector to
fire in the beam-off period. These delayed events were sorted
into g-g , g-x-ray and g-time matrices and a g-g-g cube,
allowing level schemes and half-lives to be deduced from
coincidence relations. A wide variety of targetlike isomers
have been observed from 69
171Tm up to 77
189Ir, together with a
large number of nuclei from the fission of uranium. The most
intense out-of-beam decays are those from the inelastically
excited isomers in the 180Hf target @12#, but the one-proton
transfer channels to tantalum nuclei are also strongly popu-
lated.
A new isomer was observed in 180Ta, feeding the known
states in the Kp5192 band based on the 2899 keV level
@2,3# via transitions with energies of 492 and 370 keV. The
level scheme is shown in Fig. 1. From the coincidence spec-
trum gated by the 365 keV transition @Fig. 2 ~top!# it can be
seen that the new 492 keV g ray is much weaker than the
370 keV and subsequent decays (’25% of the g-ray inten-
sity!. A probable explanation for the difference in coinci-
dence intensity is the presence of an intermediate half-life.
The time window for g-ray coincidences to be in the same
event remains open for 800 ns. A half-life of 2.060.5 ms for©2000 The American Physical Society01-1
BRIEF REPORTS PHYSICAL REVIEW C 62 057301the 3678 keV level would allow ’25% of the coincidences
to fall inside of the 800 ns window. This half-life is con-
firmed by the absence of the 492 keV transition when the
coincidence window is reduced to 20 ns @Fig. 2 ~middle!#.
~The transitions below the 22 ns isomer also have reduced
intensity in this spectrum.! The 492 keV transition can be
cleanly observed by gating on the 410 keV g ray and pro-
jecting the coincidence events observed between 40 and 800
ns earlier, as shown in Fig. 2 ~bottom!.
All of the g rays below the 4170 keV level are contami-
nated @see, for example, Fig. 2 ~top!# precluding a half-life
measurement using the g-time matrix. In addition the time
spectra for the 16.5 ms range are distorted, perhaps as a
result of the high in-beam rate. Therefore, eight g-g matrices
gated by 1.5 ms time intervals ~with 1.6 ms separating the
centroids!, for times .2 ms, were constructed. The peak
areas for the transitions above the 31 ms isomer, obtained
from spectra gated by the 365, 410, and 431 keV decays,
were plotted as a function of time, negating the problem of
contaminants. To correct for the distortion, the resulting
spectrum was divided by a normalized half-life curve corre-
sponding to a long-lived product @100 ms). ~This technique
reliably reproduced known half-lives, for example, the 10
61 ms isomer in 180Hf @12# was measured here to be 9.6
ms.) The result is shown in Fig. 3 yielding a lifetime of
t1/251765 ms. The large uncertainty arises from the pres-
ence of the ’2 ms half-life component for the 3678 keV
level and a sensitivity to the profile used to correct for the
distortion.
FIG. 1. Decay scheme for the new six-quasiparticle isomers in
180Ta observed in the present work. The spins and parities for states
below the (222) 3678 keV level are taken from Refs. @2,3#.05730No 779 keV decay was observed from the 3678 keV state
to the Kp5192 bandhead, but an upper limit can be obtained
for the partial g-ray half-life from the maximum intensity of
this transition. This yields t1/2
g .10 ms for the unobserved
779 keV transition. Comparisons with the Weisskopf single-
particle estimate show that such a half-life is only consistent
with l>3 transitions ~within a generous margin of 103) sug-
gesting a spin I>22 for the 3678 keV state. From intensity
balancing with the 410 keV M1 transition, the total electron
conversion coefficient for the 370 keV decay is aT(exp)
50.0960.08. This is consistent with electric quadrupole
@aT(E2)50.04# and electric octupole assignments
@aT(E3)50.16# , considering only those multipolarities that
lead to a spin greater than 21 \ for the ’2 ms isomer. (M2,
M3, and higher multipoles are ruled out by this analysis.!
Therefore, the most likely spin and parity assignments for
the 3678 keV state are Kp5222 and 231. Examining the
Weisskopf units ~W.u.! for the 370 keV decay favors the E2
assignment, as an E3 multipole would imply ;300 W.u.,
which is exceptionally fast for a noncollective K-forbidden
transition. Thus, the preferred tentative assignment for the
3678 keV level is Kp5(222).
There are two possible scenarios for the 492 keV transi-
tion observed above the ’2 ms isomer. Firstly, it could be
the direct decay from the isomeric state, consistent with l
<3 transitions. Alternatively, the 4170 keV level could be
the
FIG. 2. The top panel shows delayed g rays gated by the 365
keV transition in 180Ta with an 800 ns coincidence window. The
middle panel shows the ‘‘logical and’’ of two delayed spectra, ob-
tained from single gates on the 312 and 410 keV transitions with a
narrow 610 ns coincidence condition. ~A ‘‘logical and’’ compares
the counts per channel in two individual spectra, and displays the
smaller of the two per channel @13#. This helps to reduce contami-
nant g rays.! The 492 keV decay is no longer present and the
intensity of the transitions below the 22 ns isomer is reduced. The
bottom spectrum shows the ‘‘early’’ transitions which precede the
410 keV g ray by between 40 and 800 ns. Known contaminant g
rays are labeled by their energy and associated nuclide.1-2
BRIEF REPORTS PHYSICAL REVIEW C 62 057301first excited member of the rotational band associated with
the Kp5222 state, which could be fed by a low-energy ~un-
observed! transition from the ’17 ms isomer, represented by
the offset n,60 keV in Fig. 1. Such a decay would be
compatible with l<2. In both of these situations the transi-
tion rate favors a quadrupole assignment by comparison with
Weisskopf estimates. The most likely spin assignment for the
’17 ms isomer is 23, 24, or 25 \ .
In addition to the first observation of the 3678 and 4170
1n keV isomeric states, a new 1137 keV K-allowed transi-
tion, with a branching ratio of 7%, has been observed from
the 22 ns isomer to the 31 ms isomer. This is shown in Fig.
4. The 2587 keV I518 level has previously been assigned a
tentative positive parity @2,3#. The absence of a competing
quadrupole decay to the 1791 Ip5162 state favors an E3
multipolarity for the 1137 keV transition, supporting a posi-
tive parity assignment for the 22 ns isomer.
Predictions for the excitation energies, spin and parity as-
signments for low-lying six-quasiparticle isomers have been
made using Lipkin-Nogami @2# and BCS calculations @3#
~see Fig. 5!, at deformations of «250.237, «450.056 and
«250.242, «450.087, respectively. These calculations both
predict yrast Kp5241 and Kp5222 six-quasiparticle
states with configurations n$ 112 1@615# , 92 1@624# , 72 2@514#%

180Ta, plotted as a function of time. The intensities were obtained
from spectra gated by the 365, 409, and 431 keV decays ~see text
for details!. The solid line through the data represents a one-
component fit with the half-life shown.
FIG. 4. Gamma-ray spectrum produced from summing the spec-

keV transitions. The 1137 keV transition can be clearly seen.05730^ p$ 92

spectively. The predicted energies are E24153775 keV and
E22
2
53188 keV from Ref. @2# and E24154133 keV and
E22
2
53314 keV from Ref. @3#. ~Note that these energies
include residual nucleon-nucleon interactions.! These calcu-
lated states have the most favored residual interactions pos-
sible as given by the Gallagher-Moszkowski coupling rules
@14#, which result in a lowering of the energies with respect
to unfavored configurations. Saitoh et al. @3# point out that
these energies are ‘‘only accurate to within 6400 keV but
that it is reasonable to assume that this Kp5222 level lies
below the 212 level of the 192 band’’ at 3737 keV. As no
low-lying spin 23 \ states are predicted it is likely that the
’2 ms isomer is the calculated 222 intrinsic level, which
does lie below the 212 member of the Kp5192 band. The
Kp5(222) state qualifies as an yrast trap, as it lies below all
of the I521 levels, forcing it to decay by a l.1 transition.
The energy of the ’17 ms state observed at 41701n keV is
in good agreement with the predicted Kp5241 level. @There
FIG. 5. Observed ~Expt.! and calculated intrinsic four- and six-
quasiparticle states in 180Ta. The energies of Calc. I are taken from
Ref. @2# and Calc. II are taken from Ref. @3#. Residual nucleon-
nucleon interactions are included in the energies of both calcula-
tions. See text for details.1-3
BRIEF REPORTS PHYSICAL REVIEW C 62 057301are no low-lying K525 states predicted and a Kp5262 state
~discussed later! is calculated to be 1029 keV higher than the
Kp5241 state @2#.#
Dracoulis et al. @2# have calculated the energies of the
most favored eight-quasiparticle states. The lowest of these
is a Kp5262 level with the configuration n$ 92 1@624# ,
7
2
2@514# , 72 2@503# , 52 2@512# , 32 2@512#% ^ p$ 92 2@514# ,
7
2
1@404# , 52 1@402#%, predicted at 4804 keV, including re-
sidual interactions. No candidates for transitions from this
possible isomer to the 41701n keV state have been identi-
fied in the present study, but this together with higher states
provide a challenging objective for future studies.05730In summary, two new high-spin six-quasiparticle yrast
isomers have been populated in the nucleus 180Ta, using
deep inelastic reactions with a 238U beam. These are the
highest spin and highest seniority K isomers yet identified
with deep inelastic reactions. The excitation energies of the
new intrinsic states are found to be in good agreement with
predictions of multiquasiparticle calculations, and configura-
tion assignments have been made.
